2193768.question: How can young people avoid injuries when weight training?
takeaways: Always warm up before lifting
Stop when your form breaks down - don't push through with bad technique
Train under proper supervision
Increase weight gradually to avoid overuse injuries
2193768.title: Musculoskeletal injuries caused by weight training: guidelines for prevention

2205781.question: Does building muscle help prevent injuries in athletes?
2205781.summary: Reviews how muscle and connective tissue adapt to resistance training, resulting in greater tissue mass and increased tensile strength. Proposes periodization as a training model to increase performance while reducing overtraining and injury.
takeaways: Pre-season and in-season strength training reduces injury rates
Varying your training (different exercises, intensities) prevents overtraining
Stronger muscles and tendons are more resistant to injury
Regular resistance training creates protective changes in your tissues
2205781.title: Muscle conditioning and muscle injuries

2396614.journal: American Journal of Diseases of Children
2396614.question: What types of weight training injuries happen most often in teens?
takeaways: Muscle strains are the most common injury (about 3 in 4 injuries)
The back is the most commonly injured area (nearly 6 in 10 injuries)
Good form and supervision prevent most injuries
Most injuries are minor and heal quickly
2396614.title: Weight-training injuries in adolescents

limitations: sample size not specified in abstract

2796409.question: Do older adults still get hormonal benefits from weight training?
takeaways: Weight training boosts growth hormone and testosterone at any age
Younger people show a stronger hormonal response than older adults
Both single workouts and regular training affect hormone levels
Older adults can still gain 37-39% more strength with training
2796409.title: Effects of progressive resistance training on growth hormone and testosterone levels in young and elderly subjects

3173042.question: Do women build muscle at the same rate as men?
takeaways: Women and men gain muscle at similar percentage rates
Upper arm muscles grew 16-23% in both sexes after 16 weeks
Both groups made significant strength gains
Men gain more total muscle, but percentage gains are similar
3173042.title: Muscle hypertrophy in men and women

9789866.question: Is weight training safe for people recovering from heart problems?
9789866.summary: Reviews evidence supporting resistance training as part of cardiac rehabilitation programs, demonstrating safety and benefits for patients with heart disease.
takeaways: Weight training has been part of heart rehab programs since the mid-1980s
Studies show it's safe in various stages of cardiac recovery
Weight training actually had fewer complications than cardio alone
Patients gain strength and better daily function
9789866.title: Role of resistance training in heart disease

10647555.question: Do you need to do multiple sets per exercise, or is one set enough?
takeaways: One set works almost as well as three sets for building strength
No real difference in body changes between groups
One-set routines stay effective even after training for a year
Casual exercisers can get good results with less time in the gym
10647555.title: Single versus multiple sets in long-term recreational weightlifters

17119361.question: Can weight training stunt a child's growth?
takeaways: Supervised weight training is safe for kids before and during puberty
No evidence of growth problems with proper supervision
Growth plate injuries are rare when using good form and appropriate weights
Low trainer-to-kid ratios are important for safety
17119361.title: Weight training in youth-growth, maturation, and safety: an evidence-based review

19620931.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research

limitations: position statement format rather than systematic review

19620931.question: Should children and teenagers do resistance training?
19620931.summary: NSCA position statement updating 1996 recommendations on youth resistance training, addressing risks, benefits, and program design for children and adolescents.
takeaways: Yes - it's safe and effective with proper supervision and age-appropriate programs
Benefits include better strength, motor skills, and sports performance
Injury risk is low with qualified supervision and proper technique
The NSCA supports resistance training for healthy kids and teens
19620931.title: Youth resistance training: Updated position statement paper from the National Strength and Conditioning Association

20139328.question: What causes most weight training injuries in the US?
takeaways: About 90% of injuries happen with free weights (barbells and dumbbells)
Most injuries (65%) happen when weights are dropped on someone
Lower back and shoulders are the most commonly injured areas
Muscle strains account for nearly half of all injuries
20139328.title: Epidemiology of weight training-related injuries presenting to United States emergency departments, 1990 to 2007

20182386.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
20182386.question: Are deep squats bad for your knees?
20182386.summary: Reviews biomechanical literature on squat depth, knee position, and spinal loading. Addresses common concerns about deep squats and knees traveling past toes.
takeaways: Deep squats are safe when done with proper form
Squatting to parallel builds the most thigh muscle
Deeper squats work your glutes and hamstrings more
Knees going past toes is fine and often necessary for good form
20182386.title: Squatting kinematics and kinetics and their application to exercise performance

20508476.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
20508476.question: Why do so many lifters hurt their shoulders?
takeaways: Up to 36% of weight training injuries happen to the shoulder
Doing too many pushing exercises creates muscle imbalances
Rotator cuff and shoulder blade muscles are often neglected
Balance pushing and pulling movements to protect your shoulders
20508476.title: Shoulder injuries attributed to resistance training: a brief review

21131862.question: How little can you train and still keep your gains?
takeaways: Young adults kept muscle size training just 3 sets per week total
Older adults (60-75) need about 1/3 of their original training volume
Strength holds up well even with very reduced training
Keeping weights heavy matters more than doing lots of sets
21131862.title: Exercise dosing to retain resistance training adaptations in young and older adults

21178368.question: Is intense weight training safe for young elite athletes?
takeaways: Weight training is safe and effective for building youth strength
No problems when properly supervised with age-appropriate precautions
Benefits include better strength, power, and sports performance
Programs must be designed for the athlete's age and development
21178368.title: High-intensity and resistance training and elite young athletes

22978257.question: Does menopause cause weight gain?
takeaways: Weight gain is mostly due to aging, not menopause itself
Hormonal changes shift where fat is stored (more around the belly)
Lower estrogen promotes fat storage around the midsection
Hormone therapy may partly prevent these body changes
22978257.title: Understanding weight gain at menopause

23287827.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
23287827.question: Can you tell how recovered you are just by how you feel?
takeaways: Self-rated recovery dropped significantly after hard training
How recovered you feel matches actual muscle damage markers
Your perceived recovery is a reliable indicator of actual recovery
Simple self-assessment can help guide when to train hard again
23287827.title: Changes in perceived recovery status scale following high-volume muscle damaging resistance exercise

limitations: heterogeneity in injury definitions across studies

27328853.question: How dangerous is powerlifting, weightlifting, or CrossFit?
takeaways: Weight-training sports have lower injury rates than team sports
Shoulder, lower back, and knee are the most common injury sites
Good technique and gradual weight increases reduce injury risk
Injury rates are similar across age, sex, and weight classes
27328853.title: The epidemiology of injuries across the weight-training sports

27433992.question: Do you build more muscle by doing more sets?
takeaways: Yes - more weekly sets generally means more muscle growth
10+ sets per muscle per week builds significantly more muscle than fewer than 5
Each additional set provides a small extra benefit
This applies to both beginners and experienced lifters
27433992.title: Dose-response relationship between weekly resistance training volume and increases in muscle mass: a systematic review and meta-analysis

28275997.question: Does drinking water after sweating actually improve performance?
takeaways: Rehydrating helps most for longer, continuous exercise
Benefits are greater when exercising in hot conditions
The longer you exercise, the more important hydration becomes
Losing more than 2% of body weight in sweat hurts endurance
28275997.title: The effect of fluid intake following dehydration on subsequent athletic and cognitive performance: a systematic review and meta-analysis

limitations: heterogeneity in protein sources and timing

28698222.question: Does protein powder actually help build muscle?
takeaways: Protein supplements add about 2.5 kg (5.5 lbs) to strength gains
Extra protein adds about 0.3 kg (0.7 lbs) of muscle
Benefits max out at about 1.6 g protein per kg body weight daily
Older people benefit less; experienced lifters benefit more
28698222.title: A systematic review, meta-analysis and meta-regression of the effect of protein supplementation on resistance training-induced gains in muscle mass and strength in healthy adults

29566200.question: Does eating more fiber really improve health?
takeaways: Strong evidence for reduced pancreatic cancer and heart disease death
Good evidence for reduced overall death risk and heart disease
Based on 18 major reviews covering 298 studies
Supports recommendations to eat more fiber
29566200.title: Dietary fibre and health outcomes: an umbrella review of systematic reviews and meta-analyses

30704301.question: Does it matter if you work out in the morning or evening?
takeaways: People tend to be slightly stronger in the evening naturally
Long-term muscle and strength gains are similar regardless of training time
Training at the same time each day may matter more than which time
Your personal schedule and energy patterns should guide your choice
30704301.title: The effects of time of day-specific resistance training on adaptations in skeletal muscle hypertrophy and muscle strength: A systematic review and meta-analysis

32218059.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research

limitations: heterogeneity in training protocols across studies

32218059.question: Do men and women respond differently to weight training?
takeaways: Men and women build muscle at essentially the same rate
Women actually make larger relative gains in upper-body strength
No real difference in lower-body strength gains between sexes
Men and women can follow the same training programs
32218059.title: Sex differences in resistance training: a systematic review and meta-analysis

32576318.question: Is it better to lose weight slowly or quickly?
takeaways: Slower weight loss leads to more fat loss than rapid dieting
Gradual dieting better protects your metabolism
Both approaches preserve similar amounts of muscle
Slower dieting may be easier to maintain long-term
32576318.title: Effects of gradual weight loss v. rapid weight loss on body composition and RMR: a systematic review and meta-analysis

32661839.question: Does your menstrual cycle affect workout performance?
takeaways: Performance is slightly lower during your period (very small effect)
The biggest difference is between early and late parts of your cycle
Individual responses vary a lot - some women notice it, others don't
Overall evidence quality is low; personal tracking may help
32661839.title: The Effects of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Exercise Performance in Eumenorrheic Women: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

33332016.question: Do older men and women respond differently to weight training?
takeaways: Older women gain relatively more lower-body strength than older men
Men show larger absolute gains in strength and muscle size
Relative gains in upper-body strength and muscle size are similar
How you measure (absolute vs percentage) changes the conclusion
33332016.title: Sex Differences in Adaptations in Muscle Strength and Size Following Resistance Training in Older Adults: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

33572406.journal: International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health
33572406.question: Do female athletes actually perform worse during their period?
takeaways: Athletes often feel worse during their period and late in their cycle
Objective tests don't show consistent performance differences
Some athletes are affected more than others
Both mental and physical factors play a role
33572406.title: The Impact of Menstrual Cycle Phase on Athletes' Performance: A Narrative Review

33587549.question: Should you take diet breaks when trying to lose fat?
takeaways: Fat loss is similar whether you diet continuously or take breaks
Muscle retention is the same with either approach
Diet breaks may help reduce hunger
Breaks might help you stick to your diet without hurting results
33587549.title: Continuous versus Intermittent Dieting for Fat Loss and Fat-Free Mass Retention in Resistance-trained Adults: The ICECAP Trial

33629972.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
33629972.question: How little exercise do you need to maintain your strength?
takeaways: Young adults can maintain strength with just 1 workout per week
Older adults need about 2 sessions per week to keep muscle size
Keeping weights heavy is the most important factor
You can cut way back on volume if you keep intensity high
33629972.title: Maintaining physical performance: the minimal dose of exercise needed to preserve endurance and strength over time

35247352.question: How many steps per day do you need to live longer?
takeaways: More steps means lower death risk, up to a point
For adults 60+, benefits max out at 6,000-8,000 steps/day
For adults under 60, benefits continue up to 8,000-10,000 steps/day
The most active people had 40-53% lower death risk
35247352.title: Daily steps and all-cause mortality: a meta-analysis of 15 international cohorts

35471634.question: Should women train differently during different parts of their cycle?
takeaways: Strength may peak during the first half of your cycle (before ovulation)
Estrogen helps with muscle recovery and protein use
Training harder in the first half may produce better results
More research is needed to give practical recommendations
35471634.title: Effects of Follicular and Luteal Phase-Based Menstrual Cycle Resistance Training on Muscle Strength and Mass

limitations: low to very low certainty evidence

36283059.question: Does weight training help with menopause symptoms?
takeaways: Weight training significantly reduces hot flash frequency
It improves physical function and bone density
It helps reduce body fat compared to not exercising
No serious side effects were reported in the studies
36283059.title: Resistance training for postmenopausal women: systematic review and meta-analysis

36334240.question: Do you need to train to complete failure to build muscle?
takeaways: Training to failure provides only a tiny extra benefit for muscle growth
Pushing closer to failure helps slightly more than stopping early
How much weight you lift doesn't change this finding
Stopping a rep or two short of failure works well for most people
36334240.title: Influence of Resistance Training Proximity-to-Failure on Skeletal Muscle Hypertrophy: A Systematic Review with Meta-analysis

36749350.question: Can exercise improve bone density after menopause?
takeaways: Exercise does improve bone density in postmenopausal women
Based on 80 studies with 94 different training programs
Combining weights with jumping exercises works best for hips and spine
Heavy weights (70%+ of max) three times per week may be optimal
36749350.title: Exercise training and bone mineral density in postmenopausal women: an updated systematic review and meta-analysis of intervention studies with emphasis on potential moderators

37033884.journal: Frontiers in Sports and Active Living
37033884.question: Should women plan their training around their menstrual cycle?
takeaways: Current evidence doesn't show cycle phase affects strength
It's too early to conclude hormones affect training results
Cycle-based training planning isn't practical due to individual variation
Study quality on this topic is generally poor
37033884.title: Current evidence shows no influence of women's menstrual cycle phase on acute strength performance or adaptations to resistance exercise training

37181269.question: Do diet breaks help women lose fat more effectively?
takeaways: Fat loss and muscle retention were the same with or without breaks
Metabolism stayed the same in both groups
Diet breaks may help reduce urges to overeat
Mental benefits may exist even without physical advantages
37181269.title: The Effects of Intermittent Diet Breaks during 25% Energy Restriction on Body Composition and Resting Metabolic Rate in Resistance-Trained Females: A Randomized Controlled Trial

37181372.question: Does exercise help with sleep problems during menopause?
takeaways: Exercise significantly reduces insomnia symptoms
Benefits are strongest for women with existing sleep problems
Various exercise types (yoga, cardio, walking) all help
Exercise is recommended as a drug-free option for menopausal sleep issues
37181372.title: The effect of exercise intervention on improving sleep in menopausal women: a systematic review and meta-analysis

37383396.question: How does exercise change body composition after menopause?
takeaways: Exercise increases muscle mass and lean body mass
It decreases body fat, especially around the midsection
Waist circumference is effectively reduced
Based on 101 studies with nearly 5,700 postmenopausal women
37383396.title: The effects of exercise training on body composition in postmenopausal women: a systematic review and meta-analysis

limitations: risk of bias in included studies

37462808.question: Can getting more sleep improve athletic performance?
takeaways: Extra sleep and napping show the most promise
All studies on sleep extension showed better performance
Benefits include faster reactions, better sprinting, and sport skills
Extending sleep to 10 hours improved basketball shooting by 9%
37462808.title: The impact of sleep interventions on athletic performance: a systematic review

38118410.question: Is there a limit to how much protein your body can use after a workout?
takeaways: 100g of protein produced bigger and longer-lasting muscle-building effects than 25g
The muscle-building response continued for over 12 hours with larger doses
Extra protein wasn't just burned off as fuel
Previous limits on per-meal protein may have been too conservative
38118410.title: The anabolic response to protein ingestion during recovery from exercise has no upper limit in magnitude and duration in vivo in humans

38251305.question: When during your cycle are you strongest?
takeaways: Late in the first half of your cycle (before ovulation) is optimal for static strength
Around ovulation is optimal for dynamic strength
During your period is the least favorable time for all strength types
Based on 22 studies with 433 women
38251305.title: The Influence of Menstrual Cycle Phases on Maximal Strength Performance in Healthy Female Adults: A Systematic Review with Meta-Analysis

39485653.question: How common is undereating in athletes, and what are the consequences?
takeaways: Nearly half (45%) of athletes studied were not eating enough
Undereating hurts endurance, coordination, and concentration
Athletes who undereat have more bone stress injuries
Both male and female athletes are affected equally
39485653.title: Low energy availability and relative energy deficiency in sport: a systematic review and meta-analysis

41343037.question: Is there a point of diminishing returns for training volume?
takeaways: Yes - more sets help, but gains slow down as volume increases
Diminishing returns are more obvious for strength than muscle growth
Training frequency has small effects on muscle but clear benefits for strength
How you count sets affects what the research shows
41343037.title: The resistance training dose response: meta-regressions exploring the effects of weekly volume and frequency on muscle hypertrophy and strength gains

undefined.journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
undefined.question: How much training volume do experienced lifters need?
takeaways: Experienced lifters maintained muscle with just 3 sets per muscle per week
You must keep weights heavy and training frequent when reducing volume
Hormonal responses were similar across different training volumes
Low volume maintains gains, but higher volume may build more muscle
undefined.title: The effect of weight training volume on hormonal output and muscular size and function
